summary: In this 2009 Supreme Court of Ghana ruling, 28 members of the Kejetia Traders Association (Mighty 18), led by Agyenim-Boateng, applied for an order of contempt against S.K. Boateng (Chairman) and Evelyn Akuffo Oduro (Manageress, National Investment Bank, Kumasi) for allegedly violating a stay of execution by withdrawing GH392,062.90 in compensation funds. The funds were held in trust following a property acquisition dispute. The applicants claimed the 1st Respondent withdrew the money after being served with a motion for stay of execution. However, the court found that the motion was filed on 28th July 2008, while the bulk of withdrawals occurred between 6th and 20th June 2008, prior to any stay application. The 1st Respondent's earlier affidavit stating he withdrew funds after service was corrected as a genuine mistake, supported by a bank statement (Exhibit KA7). The court held that contempt requires wilful disobedience of a clear court order, proven beyond reasonable doubt, which the applicants failed to establish. Therefore, the application for contempt was dismissed.
verdict: The application for contempt was dismissed due to lack of wilful disobedience and absence of a court order at the time of withdrawal.
winningSide: S.K. Boateng and Evelyn Akuffo Oduro (Respondents)
citations: Republic v High Court Accra; Ex Parte Laryea Mensah, [1998-99] SCGLR 360
Re Effiduase Stool Affairs (No 2) Republic vrs Numapau, President of the National House of Chiefs and others, Ex-parte Ameyaw II No. 2 [1998-99] SCGLR 639
Republic vrs. SITO I Ex-parte Fordjour [20012002] SCGLR 322
rationaleHighlights: The applicants failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the respondents committed wilful contempt.
The 1st Respondent's affidavit error was deemed inadvertent and corrected with documentary evidence.
All major withdrawals occurred before the stay of execution was filed, thus no court order was violated.
Contempt requires a clear, unambiguous court order and knowledge of its terms by the respondent.
The burden of proof in contempt cases is criminal standard: beyond reasonable doubt.
